title: How to Get Website Information Using Command Prompt

steps.title: Open Start .
steps.content: Open Start . Click the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Search for Command Prompt.
steps.content: Search for Command Prompt. Type in command prompt to bring up a list of matching results.

steps.title: Click Command Prompt.
steps.content: Click Command Prompt. It's at the top of the Start menu. Doing so will open the Command Prompt window.

steps.title: Ping the web address you want to check.
steps.content: Ping the web address you want to check. You can "ping" the nearest website server to see how far away the server is in milliseconds: Type in ping website.com where "website" is your website's name. Press ↵ Enter . Press ↵ Enter again to stop the ping.

steps.title: Trace the website's route.
steps.content: Trace the website's route. Sending a "traceroute" request to your website will show the route the request takes, documenting any server addresses between you and the website: Type in tracert website.com where "website" is the website's name. Press ↵ Enter . Review the path your request took (sections with asterisks are instances in which the request timed out).

steps.title: Check the DNS information for the website.
steps.content: Check the DNS information for the website. You can see the website's DNS address, which differs from the IP address, by doing the following: Type in nslookup website.com where "website" is the name of the website. Press ↵ Enter . Review the website's DNS addresses.
